items.title: Teens flock to alternative apps after social media ban
items.description: The Commonwealth's long-awaited social media ban for under-16s came into effect this month. But some experts note a rise in alternatives to popular platforms as teens find ways to stay active on social media.

items.title: How investigators pieced together the plot to target Bondi
items.description: Security camera footage captured the Bondi Beach gunmen carrying what appears to be firearms out of a south-west Sydney property on the morning of the terror attack, court documents reveal.

items.title: Gas lobby turns to liquid under pressure
items.description: The gas export industry has cost the nation dearly. East coast prices trebled soon after exports began.

items.title: Fast cars and big debts: On the trail of a career con man
items.description: Steven Cubis hides behind a charming facade, but his former lover and friends say the career con man ruined them financially and emotionally long before he was caught up in allegations of a multi-million-dollar fraud.

items.title: FRV sues firefighters union over $1.6m in taxpayer-funded 'service fees'
items.description: Taxpayers have funded $1.6 million in payments to the firefighters union via Fire Rescue Victoria, court documents allege, under an income protection scheme the state's fire chief has said should outrage all Victorians.

items.title: Scientists find 20 new species in Pacific twilight zone

featured_image.name: In the ocean's 'twilight zone,' divers risk their lives in search of mysteries

items.description:
Researchers from the California Academy of Sciences have unveiled at least 20 potential new marine species from the depths of the Pacific Ocean near Guam, along with troubling evidence of warming temperatures and plastic pollution in one of Earth's least explored ecosystems.

In November, a team of scientific divers retrieved 13 autonomous reef monitoring structures, or ARMS, that had been silently collecting data for nearly eight years at depths up to 330 feet in the ocean's "twilight zone"[1][2][3]. The expedition yielded 2,000 specimens, including 100 species documented for the first time in the region[1][2][4].

items.title: Russian general killed in Moscow car bombing

featured_image.name: Car bomb kills senior Russian general in Moscow: Officials ...

items.description: A senior Russian general has been killed after an explosive device detonated under his car in southern Moscow on Monday morning, in what investigators say may have been an assassination carried out by Ukrainian special services.[1][2][3][4] Lieutenant General Fanil Sarvarov, 56, head of the Russian General Staff’s army operational training directorate, died after his Kia Sorento exploded around 7 a.m. in the capital’s Yasenevo district, Russia’s Investigative Committee said.[5][1][2][3][4]

items.title: Ellison personally guarantees $40B in Warner Bros bid

featured_image.name: Larry Ellison gives $40.4 billion guarantee for Paramount bid for ...

items.description:
Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison has moved to shore up Paramount Skydance’s hostile pursuit of Warner Bros. Discovery, offering an “irrevocable personal guarantee” of $40.4 billion in equity financing for the $108 billion all‑cash bid after Warner Bros.’ board rejected an earlier, trust‑backed proposal and urged shareholders to stick with a rival deal from Netflix.[1][2][3]

The revised offer, unveiled Monday, keeps Paramount Skydance’s cash price at $30 per share for 100% of Warner Bros. Discovery but converts a contentious commitment from an Ellison family trust into a direct, personal backstop from Ellison himself.[4][5][6] Paramount has also agreed to match Netflix’s $5.8 billion regulatory reverse breakup fee, up from $5 billion, in an effort to narrow the perceived gap in deal certainty ahead of a key tender period for Warner Bros. Discovery investors.[7][8][9]

items.title: Harvard's Loeb calls interstellar comet natural

featured_image.name: 3I/ATLAS as a cosmic messenger: Avi Loeb on the future of interstellar time capsules

items.description:
Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb has affirmed that interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS is "most likely natural," tempering months of speculation about extraterrestrial technology while simultaneously proposing an unconventional use for such cosmic visitors: delivering humanity's messages to the stars[1][2][3].

In a paper published December 21 on Medium, Loeb outlined how interstellar objects could serve as faster messengers than humanity's current efforts, dramatically reducing the time needed to send artifacts beyond our solar system[1][4]. The timing of Loeb's proposal came just two days after 3I/ATLAS made its closest approach to Earth on December 19, passing within 168 million miles of our planet[5][6].

"Riding 3I/ATLAS offers the benefit of reaching interstellar space by the year ~10,000 CE instead of the year ~30,000 CE," Loeb wrote, comparing the comet's trajectory to NASA's Voyager 1 spacecraft[1][4]. The Voyager probe, launched in 1977, travels at 17 kilometers per second and will require another 28,000 years to reach the assumed edge of the solar system, according to Loeb's calculations[1]. In contrast, 3I/ATLAS moves at 60 kilometers per second, cutting the journey time by more than two-thirds[1].

items.title: NBA and FIBA to launch new European basketball league in 2027

featured_image.name: As NBA plans for new pro league in Europe progress, EuroLeague ...

items.description:
The NBA and world governing body FIBA will begin formally approaching European clubs and owners in January about joining a new continent-wide basketball league, with a working launch target of October 2027.[1][2][3] The project, years in the making, would create a top-tier competition backed by the NBA’s commercial machine but structured around Europe’s traditional promotion-and-qualification model.[1][4][5]

At the heart of the proposal is a hybrid format that combines guaranteed places for a core group of clubs with annual access via sporting merit. Current models under discussion focus on a 16-team league with 12 permanent members and four qualification spots, earned through FIBA’s Basketball Champions League or a postseason tournament.[6][1][5][2] All clubs playing in FIBA-affiliated European leagues would have a theoretical path into the new competition.[6][1][5]

FIBA secretary general Andreas Zagklis said the format “respects European sport model principles by offering any ambitious club in the continent a fair pathway to the top,” while NBA commissioner Adam Silver described the initiative as “an enormous opportunity” to grow the professional game in Europe.[6][1][2][3]

items.title: 'Extremely cunning': Taipei metro attacker planned assault for over a year
items.description: Police in Taiwan say Chang Wen purchased grenades, gas canisters and respirators in the year leading up to Friday's attack.

items.title: Ukraine's $1,000 drones reshape air defense economics

featured_image.name: Ukraine deploys low-cost drones to counter Russian attacks, in photos

items.description:
Ukraine has rapidly scaled production of low-cost interceptor drones to nearly 950 units per day, fundamentally reshaping air defense as nightly Russian attacks continue to pummel cities and infrastructure. The interceptors, which cost as little as $1,000, have shot down more than 1,500 enemy drones in recent months while preserving expensive missiles for faster threats[1][2][3].

On the night of December 21-22, Russian forces launched 86 attack drones at Ukraine, with air defenses shooting down 58[4][5]. The assault followed a pattern that has intensified throughout 2025, with Russia deploying approximately 5,500 Shahed-type drones monthly against Ukrainian targets[6].

items.title: Nvidia to ship H200 AI chips to China pending Beijing approval

featured_image.name: ByteDance and Alibaba want Nvidia H200 chips after green light

items.description:
Nvidia has informed Chinese customers that it intends to begin deliveries of its H200 AI chips before the Lunar New Year in mid-February, pending government approval from Beijing, according to three sources familiar with the matter who spoke to Reuters[1][2][3][4].

The American chipmaker plans to fulfill initial orders from existing inventory, with expected shipments ranging from 5,000 to 10,000 chip modules—equivalent to approximately 40,000 to 80,000 H200 AI chips, the sources said[1][2][3]. The company has also indicated it aims to expand production capacity for these chips, with new orders anticipated to open in the second quarter of 2026[1][2][3].

However, considerable uncertainty remains, as Beijing has not yet authorized any purchases of the H200 chips[1][2][3]. "The entire plan is reliant on government approval," one source told Reuters[1][2]. "Nothing is guaranteed until we receive the official green light."

items.title: New simulations and JWST reveal black hole mysteries

featured_image.name: Interstellar's fake black holes are helping actual ...

items.description:
Astronomers have unveiled two breakthroughs that deepen understanding of how black holes behave in extreme environments, with findings reported this week revealing both the most accurate simulations of black hole behavior ever created and mounting evidence for an exotic new class of cosmic objects powered by black holes in the early universe.

A study published December 3 in The Astrophysical Journal presents the first simulations to successfully model luminous black hole accretion without simplifying assumptions, using the world's most powerful supercomputers to solve Einstein's equations of general relativity while fully accounting for radiation[1][2][3]. Meanwhile, observations from the James Webb Space Telescope suggest that mysterious "little red dots" discovered in the distant universe are actually "black hole stars"—supermassive black holes wrapped in dense gas envelopes that glow like giant stars—according to analysis published today in New Scientist[4].

items.title: Scientists boost perovskite solar cell durability in extreme heat

featured_image.name: Perovskite solar cells retain 90% output after 1,500 hours ...

items.description:
Researchers at Purdue and Emory Universities have developed a method to dramatically improve the durability of perovskite solar cells, addressing one of the most stubborn barriers to commercializing this next-generation renewable energy technology.

The team engineered a specialized ionic liquid that enables perovskite solar cells to retain 90 percent of their performance after 1,500 hours of continuous operation at 90 degrees Celsius under full sunlight conditions, according to findings published in Nature Energy in December 2025[1][2][3]. The cells achieved a power conversion efficiency of 25.9 percent while demonstrating operational resilience that surpasses previous benchmarks tested under milder conditions[2][3].

items.title: Kyrgios not offered Australian Open wildcard — yet
items.description: After a career-best year, Queenslander Priscilla Hon was among four Australian Open wildcards named on Monday, but Nick Kyrgios was not among them.

items.title: Swiss court admits climate case against cement giant Holcim

featured_image.name: Swiss court to hear landmark climate case against cement ...

items.description:
A Swiss court has agreed to hear a pioneering climate lawsuit brought by Indonesian islanders against cement giant Holcim, marking the first time climate litigation against a major corporation has been admitted in Switzerland[1][2][3]. The Cantonal Court of Zug accepted the complaint in its entirety on Monday, allowing four residents of the low-lying island of Pari to pursue compensation and emissions reductions from the world's largest cement manufacturer[1][4].

The decision represents a significant legal milestone, granting standing to plaintiffs from a developing nation to sue a Swiss corporation for climate damages in Swiss courts[1][5]. Holcim, headquartered in Zug, has indicated it will appeal the ruling[2][5].

items.title: City Beach fined $14m over 'pervasive' button battery safety failures
items.description: The Federal Court orders the fashion retailer to pay $14 million in fines after it was taken to court by the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission.

items.title: Measles cases triple in Australia as global outbreaks continue
items.description: The number of measles cases nationwide is now approaching triple the number of cases reported in 2024 as outbreaks continue around the world.

items.title: Jessica was raped by her husband. It took six years to finally secure a conviction
items.description: Jessica Seage fought for six years for the man who raped her to be convicted. Experts say her experience is a stark example of how perpetrators abuse the system to inflict more pain on their victims.

items.title: Russia says talks on US peace plan for Ukraine 'are proceeding constructively'
items.description: A Kremlin envoy says peace talks on a U.S.-proposed plan to end the nearly four-year war in Ukraine are proceeding constructively in Florida[2].

items.title: Indonesian court sentences an Australian to 12 years in prison for smuggling cocaine to Bali
items.description: Indonesian court sentences an Australian to 12 years in prison for smuggling cocaine to Bali[2].

items.title: At least 9 killed, 10 wounded in South African pub shooting
items.description: Authorities report that nine people have died and at least 10 others are injured after a shooting at a South African pub[2].

items.title: Saudi Arabia quietly expands access to its only alcohol store for non-Muslim residents
items.description: Saudi Arabia has quietly expanded access to its only alcohol store, now allowing non-Muslim Premium Residency holders to purchase alcohol legally[2].

items.title: Iraq's political future in limbo as factions vie for power
items.description: Political factions in Iraq have been maneuvering since the parliamentary election more than a month ago to form alliances that will shape the next government[2].

items.title: Australia marks Day of Reflection for Bondi Beach shooting victims
items.description: Australians are lighting candles Sunday to remember the victims of a mass shooting at a Jewish festival in Sydney's Bondi Beach[2].

items.title: US Coast Guard seizes second sanctioned vessel in the Caribbean, officials say
items.description: The U.S. Coast Guard has interdicted a second sanctioned vessel off the coast of Venezuela in international waters of the Caribbean Sea[2].

items.title: Egypt's el-Sissi urges UN Security Council reforms for Africa's larger role
items.description: Egypt’s President Abdel-Fattah el-Sissi has called for changes in the U.N. Security Council to give Africa a bigger role in global decisions[2].

items.title: Australian state plans tougher laws against displaying extremist flags after Bondi shooting
items.description: The Australian state of New South Wales is proposing a ban on public displays of Islamic State group flags and extremist symbols[2].

items.title: Pakistani court sentences former PM Imran Khan and wife to 17 years in graft case
items.description: A Pakistani court has convicted former Prime Minister Imran Khan and his wife, Bushra Bibi, sentencing them to 17 years in prison[2].
